record.name: Poverty of the Stimulus (Pullum & Scholz 2002)
record.work: Empirical assessment of stimulus poverty arguments
record.position: Linguistic nativism True
record.description:
Pullum & Scholz (2002:15) "there could be positive evidence for the correctness of some rule or principle, evidence that could be found in language use by an adult linguist doing a really intensive search, but would not emerge in conversational data anywhere near often enough to guarantee that any particular child would ever encounter it."


NB Pullum & Scholz introduce this as the strongest version of the poverty of the stimulus argument in favour of linguistic nativism. They introduce it in order to eventually argue against it.


a. Human infants learn their first languages either by data-driven learning or by innately-primed learning. [Disjunctive premise; by assumption.]

b. If human infants acquire their first languages via data-driven learning, then they can never learn anything for which they lack crucial evidence. [By definition of data-driven learning.]

c. But infants do in fact learn things for which they lack crucial evidence. [Empirical premise.]

d. Thus human infants do not learn their first languages by means of data-driven learning. [From (b) and (c), modus tollens.]

e. Conclusion: human infants learn their first languages by means of innately-primed learning. [From (a) and (d), disjunctive syllogism.]

record.name: Empirical premise of APS argument has not been demonstrated
record.work: Empirical assessment of stimulus poverty arguments
record.position: Linguistic nativism Unsupported
record.counterargument: Poverty of the Stimulus (Pullum & Scholz 2002) Arg is implausible
record.description:
Pullum & Scholz 2002: there is missing empirical work that would be required to establish that children do not have access to certain facts about their language during the acquisition period, facts they nonetheless eventually demonstrate knowledge of.


Empirical premise of APS: "But infants do in fact learn things for which they lack crucial evidence. [Empirical premise.]"


Five things ("APS specification schema") required to establish this premise (19):

a. ACQUIRENDUM CHARACTERIZATION: describe in detail what is alleged to be known. (descriptive linguistics)

b. LACUNA SPECIFICATION: identify a set of sentences such that if the learner had access to them, the claim of data-driven learning of the acquirendum would be supported. (formal language theory)

c. INDISPENSABILITY ARGUMENT: give reason to think that if learning were data-driven then the acquirendum could not be learned without access to sentences in the lacuna. (formal learnability theory)

d. INACCESSIBILITY EVIDENCE: support the claim that tokens of sentences in the lacuna were not available to the learner during the acquisition process. (empirical data collection)

e. ACQUISITION EVIDENCE: give reason to believe that the the acquirendum does in fact become known to learners during childhood. (experimental developmental psychology)


Given that no full corpus of utterances available to a given learner has been collected, we need to employ an assumption: "Our default assumption will be this: a construction inaccessible to infants during the language acquisition process must be rare enough that it will be almost entirely absent from corpora of text quite generally." (21)


"The corpus work that we are suggesting is necessary has not yet been undertaken" (21)


"We also need to know much more about what sort of utterances constitute the typical input to children, and what they pay attention to in that input. [...] What we claim will not be found is a construction that is learned early and occurs centrally and productively in adult speech but slumps to zero frequency in performance when young children are around." (23)

record.name: Poverty of the Stimulus (Hornstein & Lightfoot 1981)
record.position: Linguistic nativism True
record.description:
"People attain knowledge of the structure of their language for which no evidence is available in the data to which they are exposed as children." (Hornstein and Lightfoot 1981: 9)


Pullum & Scholz (2002:14-15) reconstruct the rest of the argument: "If learners come to have linguistic knowledge without being exposed to evidence that would be crucially necessary for experience-based learning, then learning is not experience-based."

record.name: Self-contradictory
record.counterargument: Poverty of the Stimulus (Hornstein & Lightfoot 1981) Arg is fallacious
record.description: Pullum & Scholz (2002:15): "Consider the position of a linguist – let us call her Angela – who claims that some grammatical fact F about a language L has been learned by some speaker S who was provided with no evidence for the truth of F. Sampson raises this question: How does Angela know that F is a fact about L? If the answer to this involves giving evidence from expressions of L, then Angela has conceded that such evidence is available, which means that S could in principle have learned F from that evidence. That contradicts what was to be shown. If, on the other hand, Angela knows L natively, and claims to know F in virtue of having come to know it during her own first-language acquisition period with the aid of innate linguistically-specific information, then Angela has presupposed nativism in an argument for nativism. That is viciously circular. And there are no other cases to consider, so the argument refutes itself."

record.name: Campbell's argument for Libertarianism
record.work: In Defence of Free Will
record.position: Libertarianism True
record.description: [Jason Winning default argument record]

record.name: Consciousness argument against teleosemantics
record.work: In Defense of Proper Functions
record.position: Teleosemantics False
record.description:
Millikan 1989:301:

  • "in the case of one's own explicit intentions at least, what one intends is given, simply and wholly given, to consciousness."
  • "But historical facts, certainly facts about one's evolutionary history, clearly are not simply given to consciousness."
  • "Hence, what one's explicit conscious intentions are could not possibly depend on facts about one's history. Q.E.D."

record.name: Relational response
record.work: In Defense of Proper Functions
record.position: Teleosemantics True
record.counterargument: Consciousness argument against teleosemantics Arg fails
record.description: Millikan 1989:301. Plenty of people have argued that meaning consists in relations between things in the head and the external world (Wittgenstein, Sellars, Putnam, Burge). Historical relations are as good candidates as any.

record.name: Millikan's argument against the view that Conceptual analysis is useful
record.work: In Defense of Proper Functions
Language, Thought, and Other Biological Categories
record.position: Conceptual analysis is useful False
record.description: Millikan 1989: 290 "Now I firmly believe that "conceptual analysis", taken as a search for necessary and sufficient conditions for the application of terms, or as a search for criteria for application by reference to which a term has the meaning it has, is a confused program, a philosophical chimera, a squaring of the circle, the misconceived child of a mistaken view of the nature of language and thought. (Not to appear opinionated. But this prejudice is painstakingly defended in [Millikan 1984] (chaps. 6, 8, and especially 9) so I have, I think, a right to it.) "

record.name: Argument for Pearl blankets vs Friston blankets
record.work: The Emperor's New Markov Blankets
record.position: Pearl blankets vs Friston blankets True
record.description:
The account of ontic Markov blankets given by Friston 2013 requires extra assumptions about how the system is represented. 


Bruineberg et al 2020:19: "The ‘Markov blanket formalism’ advocated by [Friston 2013] and described formally above does most of the work in the FEP literature when it comes to identifying internal, sensory, active, and external states. It is important to note that the partitioning of the primordial soup is not done directly, but requires a formal representation of the system. This formalizing step requires a number of additional assumptions that Friston does not provide any justification for. [...] This procedure of attributing to the territory (the dynamical system) what is a property of the map (the Bayesian network) is a clear example of the reification fallacy: treating something abstract as something concrete (without any further justification). [...] As we will show, we think that many of FEP’s proponents are using the blanket formalism in a much more metaphysically robust sense, one whose details cannot simply be assumed to follow from the formal properties of Markov blankets."


20: "While Pearl blankets are unambiguously part of the map (i.e., the graphical model), Friston blankets are best understood as parts of the territory (i.e., the system being studied)."


28: "The state of a node is not simply the joint product of its co-parents, as completely separate causal chains (the doctor’s intention vs. the patient’s intention) can produce the same outcome (i.e., spinal neuron activation). Hence the partitioning of states into internal/external by means of a Markov blanket does not necessarily equate with the boundary between agent and environment found in sensorimotor loops."

record.name: Dennett's argument against Binarism: beliefs are either real or not real
record.work: Real Patterns
record.position: Binarism: beliefs are either real or not real False
Mild realism: Beliefs are abstract objects True
record.description: Dennett 1991:27: "This conviction prevails in spite of my best efforts over the years to undermine it with various analogies: are voices in your ontology? Are centers of gravity in your ontology?"

record.name: Dretske's argument for Realism about centres of gravity
record.work: The Stance Stance
record.position: Realism about centres of gravity True
record.description:
Cited in Dennett 1991:28 fn.4


"The earth obviously exerts a gravitational attraction on all parts of the moon-not just its center of gravity. The resultant force, a vector sum, acts through a point, but this is something quite different. One should be very clear about what centers of gravity are before deciding whether to be literal about them, before deciding whether or not to be a center-of-gravity realist" (511)

record.name: Smith's argument against Realism about centres of gravity
record.work: Wit and Chutzpah
record.position: Realism about centres of gravity False
record.description:
Cited in Dennett 1991:27


Centres of gravity are useful fictions: "It is false, for example, that the gravitational attraction between the Earth and the Moon involves two point masses; but it is a good enough first approximation for many calculations." (P. Smith 1988:22)

record.name: Woodward's intuitive argument for Interventionism
record.work: Chapter 1: Introduction and Preview
record.position: Interventionism True
record.description:
The argument: Causal explanation should provide information about invariant generalisations. Interventionism meets this criterion.


Illustrated with two contrasting examples:

  • A block sliding down a plane: generalisation relating acceleration to variables describing the situation (gravity, friction) is invariant under interventions on those variables
  • A barometer in a storm: generalisation relating barometer reading to air pressure[?] is not invariant under interventions on the barometer

record.name: Woodward's payoff argument for Interventionism
record.work: Chapter 1: Introduction and Preview
record.position: Interventionism True
record.description: The argument: a theory of causal explanation should account for the benefits of accurate causal explanation. Interventionism meets this criterion: benefits accrue from accurate prediction of interventions.

record.name: Baumgartner's regress argument against i-theories
record.work: Interdefining Causation and Intervention
record.position: i-theories False
record.description: The argument: "applying the conceptual core of i-theories to concrete causal processes in experimental contexts triggers infinite regresses that render it impossible, in principle, to determine of even two concrete variables whether they are causally connected or not in a finite number of steps." (Baumgartner 2009:176)

record.name: de Souza Filho's argument that the success pattern condition is a necessary condition on intentionality
record.work: A Dual Proposal Of Minimal Conditions For Intentionality
record.position: The success pattern condition is a necessary condition on intentionality True
record.description:
Non-success-involving explanations cite causal chains to explain behaviour. They don't need to cite representational relations, because those relations aren't required in order to explain behaviour. These explanations are called "internalist".


By contrast, success-involving explanations (that involve candidate representational states) must cite representational relations in order to explain success. These explanations are called "externalist".


Non-intentional explanations are incapable of explaining successful behaviour (de Souza Filho 2022:6).

record.name: de Souza Filho's argument that the constancy mechanism condition is a necessary condition on intentionality
record.work: A Dual Proposal Of Minimal Conditions For Intentionality
record.position: The constancy mechanism condition is a necessary condition on intentionality True
record.description:
de Souza Filho 2022:13: "The identification of the same success pattern [via appeal to the constancy mechanism] endows the intentional explanation with three distinctive explanatory powers -- generalization, predictive and counterfactual powers."

  • Generalization: citing the representation enables a general explanation that "bridges across" different proximal stimuli. (Explains past and present behaviours [or successes?] in a single explanation.)
  • Predictive power: non-intentional explanations can't predict what will happen given new kinds of stimuli. (Explains[?] future behaviours [or successes?] in a single explanation.)
  • Counterfactual power: explanation provides information about counterfactual scenarios. (Explains non-actual behaviours [or successes?] in a single explanation.)

The argument mainly appears in sections 4.1 and 4.2.

record.name: de Souza Filho's argument for the dual proposal
record.work: A Dual Proposal Of Minimal Conditions For Intentionality
record.position: Dual proposal: success pattern and constancy mechanism True

record.name: The liberality objection
record.work: A Dual Proposal Of Minimal Conditions For Intentionality
record.position: The success pattern condition is a sufficient condition on minimal intentionality False
record.description:
de Souza Filho 2022:4 cites Fodor 1986, Burge 2010, Rescorla 2013, Schulte 2015 and Sterenly 1995 as offering versions of this objection.


  1. The explanatory role criterion says that for a state to be considered intentional, "There should be something that the intentional explanation is capable of explaining which the non-intentional explanation cannot explain." (de Souza Filho 2002:5)
  2. In the case of sensory states, intentional explanation does not explain anything that non-intentional explanation cannot explain.
  3. (C) If the explanatory role criterion is upheld, sensory states should not be considered intentional.

record.name: The universal acid counterargument
record.work: A Dual Proposal Of Minimal Conditions For Intentionality
record.description:
Any naturalist theory of intentionality is open to the objection that any intentional explanation could in principle be rephrased in non-intentional terms.


So in order to apply the liberality objection, you must either be an eliminativist or come up with some reason why your theory [e.g. Burge's] is not too liberal compared to the one you're complaining about [e.g. Millikan's].

record.name: de Souza Filho's intuitive objection
record.work: A Dual Proposal Of Minimal Conditions For Intentionality
record.position: The success pattern condition is a sufficient condition on minimal intentionality False
record.description:
I'm a bit confused about this argument, so I will cite the paragraphs in full. de Souza Filho 2022:10:


Tropistic systems satisfy the success pattern condition: their behavioural outputs have success patterns and they use the tropistic states as proxies for the relevant external conditions to pursue their biological goals. What happens is that they are so simple that it is very implausible that the positing of tropistic states as representational is explanatorily justified. But why is it so implausible?


A full response to this question will have to wait until the next sections. However, for the present purpose it is sufficient to point out that the tokening of a tropistic state is fully chained to a very specific stimulus (Sterelny, 1995): in the case of the paramecium, light stimulus; in the case of the anaerobic bacterium, magnetic stimulus, etc. That is, if the stimulus is present, the tropistic state is tokened, and, so, triggers the behavioural output; if the stimulus is absent, there is no tokening at all. But then it becomes very implausible that the positing of the tropistic state as representational could give rise to the distinctive explanatory power of intentional explanations. How could tropistic systems harbour representational states with such chained behaviour? Genuine intentional explanations simply have a more distinctive explanatory role. The positing of tropistic states as representational states is not explanatorily justified.


I can't see this as anything but an appeal to intuition, and it's an intuition I don't necessarily share.

record.name: My knee-jerk reaction counterargument
record.counterargument: de Souza Filho's argument that the constancy mechanism condition is a necessary condition on intentionality Arg fails
record.description:
Constancy mechanisms come in degrees of sophistication. Any sensory state, no matter how primitive, could be said to employ a constancy mechanism in some sense.


de Souza Filho's argument was intended to cut between states that seem to vary by degrees. But since constancy mechanisms themselves vary by degrees, they can't do the cutting his argument requires.

record.name: Argument for Extended active inference describes the causal reciprocal relationship between an individual organism and its cognitive niche
record.work: Limiting the explanatory scope of extended active inference: the implications of a causal pattern analysis of selective niche construction, developmental niche construction, and organism-niche coordination dynamics
record.position: Extended active inference describes the causal reciprocal relationship between an individual organism and its cognitive niche True
record.description:
Fabry 2021:15: 

As it stands, the extended active inference account does not capture selective niche construction, for it remains silent on the selection pressures induced by niche construction activities by an entire population across multiple generations. Furthermore, the extended active inference account does not capture developmental niche construction, because its focus is on the individual organism, rather than on an entire population (or sub-population) of organisms that modifies the cognitive niche across two (or more) generations, thereby changing the array of possible phenotypic traits. Contrary to the stipulation by Constant et al. (2020), then, extended active inference does not capture “a sort of hybrid between the concepts of the selective, developmental, and cognitive niches” (p. 2), but organism-niche coordination dynamics.


Also the comparison with extended cognition indicates that we're talking about the here-and-now, not cross-generational effects.

record.name: Argument that it is false that Minimizing free energy is sufficient for life
record.work: The free energy principle: it's not about what it takes, it's about what took you there
record.position: Minimizing free energy is sufficient for life False
record.description:
Simple numerical example: Constant 2021:6-12.


An organism with the wrong priors can minimize free energy and be guaranteed to die.

record.name: Argument that it is false that Minimizing expected free energy requires sophisticated capacities for counterfactual reasoning
record.work: Is free-energy minimisation the mark of the cognitive?
record.position: Minimizing expected free energy requires sophisticated capacities for counterfactual reasoning False
record.description:
E.Coli, yeast, slime mold and plants all use cues to drive anticipatory behaviour.

These are all examples of minimizing expected free energy.

[Perhaps missing premise: these are all not examples of counterfactual reasoning.]

Therefore, minimizing expected free energy does not require capacities for counterfactual reasoning.

record.name: Kiverstein & Sims's Argument that Allostasis is sufficient for cognition
record.work: Is free-energy minimisation the mark of the cognitive?
record.position: Allostasis is sufficient for cognition True

record.name: Corcoran et al's argument that it is false that Allostasis is sufficient for cognition
record.work: From allostatic agents to counterfactual cognisers: active inference, biological regulation, and the origins of cognition
record.position: Allostasis is sufficient for cognition False
record.description:
Corcoran et al 2020:34: "First, we should acknowledge that there may be few substantive differences between
the kinds of organisms we designate as hierarchical or allostatic agents, and the biological systems Godfrey-Smith and others would identify as exhibiting ‘minimal’
or ‘proto-cognitive’ capacities (e.g., Godfrey-Smith 2002, 2016b).50 Both categories imply systems that track relevant states in their (internal and external) environments, and exploit this information to adaptively regulate their activity. Both categories also imply some form of evolutionary precedence over ‘fully-fledged’ cognitive
agents—cognition ‘proper’ builds on the foundations laid by allostatic/proto-cognitive architectures.
The problem with such terminology is that it implies the ascription of some form
of cognitive capacity, while remaining opaque as to its precise relation to ‘fullblown’ cognition—including the reason for its segregation from the latter (see Lyon
2019, for an extended critique). Is there some fundamental cognitive ingredient that
proto-cognition lacks, or is it simply a scaled-down, severely degraded version of
(say) animal cognition? If the latter, is the distinction between proto- and ‘genuine’
cognition marked by a critical boundary, or is the difference gradual and indeterminate? Godfrey-Smith explicitly endorses some variety of the latter view, frequently
remarking that cognition ‘shades-off’ into other biological processes. But if protocognitive organisms ultimately fail to qualify as cognitive agents,51 such talk may
obscure a fundamental discontinuity."

record.search_key: Argument that FEP models exacerbate a trade-off between generality and biological plausibility
record.name: Argument that FEP models exacerbate a trade-off between generality and biological plausibility
record.work: Non-equilibrium thermodynamics and the free energy principle in biology
record.position: FEP models exacerbate a trade-off between generality and biological plausibility True
record.description:
There is "a fundamental mismatch between its [i.e. model-building grounded in the FEP's] physics assumptions and properties of its biological targets"


Colombo & Palacios 2021:10-13: Three aspects of biological systems that jeopardise representing them as random dynamical systems:

  1. They have more degrees of freedom
  2. Their symmetries are more unstable
  3. Their phase spaces are more unstable -- the phase space can itself be changed by changes to the features currently represented in the space.

Further discussion

19: "Its foundations in concepts and mathematical representations from physics allow free energy theorists to build models that are applicable to theoretically any (biological) system. But, achieving this generality comes at the cost of minimal biological realism, as those models fail to accurately capture any real-world factor for most biological systems."

20: Contrast the fruitful idealizations at the heart of the Ising model: "It is in virtue of, and not despite, its simplified distortions that the Ising model plays an explanatory role in highlighting a minimal set of factors that suffice to explain how a system can undergo a phase transition between an ordered and a disordered phase in two dimensions."

20: "These idealizations should allow life scientists to tractably draw some explanation and prediction about relevant biological observables in real-world systems, and assess those predictions against measurements relevant to understanding some aspect of homeostatic processes in actual biological systems (cf., Da Costa et al. 2020, Table 1 for a summary of some existing applications of active inference models). Our contention is that the idealizations made by free energy theorists do not play these practical and epistemic roles."

record.search_key: Colombo & Palacios's argument that assumptions such as ergoditicity and NESS are implausible of biological systems
record.name: Colombo & Palacios's argument that assumptions such as ergoditicity and NESS are implausible of biological systems
record.work: Non-equilibrium thermodynamics and the free energy principle in biology
record.position: Assumptions such as ergoditicity and NESS are implausible of biological systems True
record.description:
Ergodicity: Colombo & Palacios 2021:13-16


  • 14: For the [ergodic] theorem [Birkhoff 1931] to be meaningful, you have to show that the convergence rate is "plausible"; however, for even simple systems, this rate (which is a duration) can be longer than the age of the universe.
  • 14: "Compared to a non-biological system, it is harder, if not unfeasible, to estimate a characteristic time needed to attain asymptotic values in most biological systems, because of non-uniformities in its dynamics."
  • 14: "As Drake et al. (2007) put it, “asymptotic behavior is seldom realized in the real world because nature happens” (168)."
  • 14: Even physical systems are not typically ergodic in real life: "it is widely recognized that most of the systems studied in statistical mechanics are most likely non ergodic".

(NB they don't seem to use the term NESS in the manuscript itself. It's possible that "random dynamical attractors" is supposed to be a synonym.)


Random dynamical attractors:

17: "Finding biologically interesting attractors in a dynamic model of a target organism is distinctively challenging compared to finding attractors in models of non-biological systems":

  • "various processes at different spatial and temporal scales—including, plasticity, development, invasion, evolution, species movement and fluctuating resources—eliminate, reshape, and replace the attractors associated with target biological systems altogether (Drake et al. 2007)." Some examples follow. 
  • 18: GRNs can have many different possible attractors. Not all of these have "biological significance".
  • 19: Something about Milnor attractors. The upshot is that "considerable theoretical and experimental work remains to be done, which could bridge attractors in abstract dynamical systems models and measurable observables in real-world biological systems and it is not clear whether this generality can be achieved."

record.name: Scott-Phillips's argument against Incrementalism about the origin of natural language
record.work: Speaking Our Minds: Why human communication is different, and how language evolved to make it special
record.position: Incrementalism about the origin of natural language False
record.description: Cited by Planer & Godfrey-Smith 2021. There are two forms of communication, coded and ostensive-inferential. Only humans can do the latter. Scott-Phillips says there can be no continuity between the two systems, because it's not even clear what continuity means.

record.name: Godfrey-Smith's response to Scott-Phillips's argument against Incrementalism about the origin of natural language
record.work: Communication and representation understood as sender–receiver coordination
record.position: Incrementalism about the origin of natural language True
record.counterargument: Scott-Phillips's argument against Incrementalism about the origin of natural language Arg fails
record.description:
Planer & PGS: "While we agree there are differences between paradigm cases of coded and inferential communication, we doubt that a sharp distinction can be drawn between the two categories." (765) There follows a paragraph of argument. In particular, focusing on the different levels and facets of metacognition. 

Lots of examples of tactical deception etc arrayed to justify these claims.

"And as communication comes under the control of more powerful meta-psychology, we can expect to see new semantic phenomena and/or intensification of existing ones" (766).
